content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The slide contains multiple fragments of tissue. Most of these appear to be lymph nodes, which are the round to oval, densely basophilic (purple) structures. I can count at least 12 potential lymph nodes of varying sizes. These are embedded in pale pink adipose and fibrous tissue, which is characteristic of a lymph node dissection specimen. The primary task on this slide would be to systematically examine each of these lymph nodes for evidence of metastatic cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my primary task here is to identify any lymph nodes containing metastatic tumor (positive nodes). This requires a systematic, high-magnification examination of every lymph node on the slide. The area indicated by the green box is one of these lymph nodes (specifically, it's the second distinct node from the top in the leftmost group). I am zooming in to assess its architecture and cellular composition to look for atypical epithelial cells that would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my standard workflow involves systematically examining every lymph node on the slide to look for evidence of metastasis. The green box is located on the largest lymph node on the slide, situated on the far left. I would zoom into this area to begin a high-power examination of this node. This particular spot is at the periphery of the lymphoid tissue, a crucial area to inspect as metastatic cells from carcinomas typically first arrive and colonize the subcapsular sinus. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is part of the largest lymph node on the slide, located in the upper left quadrant. At low magnification, this node appears almost entirely replaced by a dense, uniform, basophilic cell population, which is highly suspicious for massive metastatic involvement. The normal architecture of the lymph node seems to be completely effaced. I would zoom in to confirm the presence of malignant cells, characterize their morphology (e.g., glandular formation, signet ring cells, solid sheets), and assess for extranodal extension (tumor breaking through the lymph node capsule), which are all critical for staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task for this slide is to identify any lymph nodes containing metastatic cancer. I would systematically examine every piece of tissue that resembles a lymph node. The area indicated by the green box is a distinct, well-circumscribed, basophilic nodule, consistent with a lymph node. I am zooming into this specific node (the second one from the top) as part of a systematic review to assess its architecture and cellular composition for any signs of metastatic disease. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node on the slide to look for evidence of metastasis. The selected area is within one of the larger, centrally located lymph nodes. The zoom is specifically targeted at the periphery of the lymphoid tissue, near the capsule. This subcapsular sinus region is the most common initial site for tumor cells to deposit within a lymph node, so it's a critical area to scrutinize for early metastatic disease. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. I zoomed into this specific area because it contains a lymph node that appears suspicious even at low power. The node shows a solid, basophilic (dark purple) appearance, suggesting its normal architecture is effaced by an infiltrating process. Furthermore, the border with the surrounding fat appears irregular, which is a critical area to examine for extranodal extension (tumor spreading beyond the lymph node capsule), a prognostically significant finding. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because this particular fragment does not have the typical appearance of a lymph node. While other fragments are ovoid and diffusely basophilic (suggesting metastatic tumor in lymph nodes), this one is more irregular and appears to have a glandular or cribriform architecture. It is essential to examine all tissue fragments to distinguish between lymph nodes and pieces of the primary tumor. This could be a piece of the primary adenocarcinoma, and I need to zoom in to confirm its histology, assess its grade, and differentiate it from a metastatic deposit in a lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. A pathologist must systematically review every piece of tissue on the slide. The area indicated by the green box is a small, fragmented piece of tissue that is darkly stained and has an irregular, somewhat glandular architecture even at low power. This appearance is highly suspicious for tumor. I would zoom into this area to confirm if it is a fragment of the primary adenocarcinoma, a completely effaced metastatic lymph node, or a tumor deposit in soft tissue. Differentiating between these possibilities is critical for accurate staging of the cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every piece of tissue on the slide for accurate staging. The area highlighted by the green box contains several small, dark, and irregular tissue fragments. Unlike the more defined lymph nodes, their morphology at low power is ambiguous but their dark color suggests they are highly cellular and likely represent tumor tissue. It is crucial to zoom in on such fragments to determine if they are part of the primary tumor, a completely effaced metastatic lymph node, or a non-nodal tumor deposit (which would have staging implications, e.g., N1c). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the standard procedure for a cancer resection case is to meticulously examine every lymph node submitted. The area indicated by the green box is one of the larger, more cellular-appearing lymph nodes on the slide (specifically, the large node on the right side). I would zoom into this area to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification. The key question is whether this node is benign (reactive) or if it contains metastatic tumor cells from the colorectal primary. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because of the presence of a distinct, dark, linear artifact on the edge of a piece of tissue that appears to be a lymph node. This feature is atypical and stands out from the surrounding biological structures. It is crucial to determine if this is an exogenous material, such as ink from specimen marking, carbon from electrocautery, or a foreign body like a suture, versus an endogenous process like unusual calcification. Identifying such features is important to avoid misinterpretation and to understand their context relative to the lymph node tissue. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it contains a distinct, ovoid, basophilic structure consistent with a lymph node. In a colorectal cancer staging case, it is mandatory to examine every lymph node to determine the N stage (nodal involvement). This particular node is located in the bottom right corner of the slide. My goal is to assess its architecture at high magnification to look for any evidence of metastatic tumor cells, which would upstage the cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my standard procedure is to meticulously examine every single lymph node on the slide to search for evidence of metastasis. The highlighted area is one of the lymph nodes located in the lower right quadrant of the slide. Even though it appears uniformly basophilic at low power, it must be examined at higher magnification to rule out small metastatic deposits (micrometastases) which might not be obvious from a distance. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a section of a lymph node characterized by a dense, diffuse infiltrate of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. The surrounding tissue at the periphery is adipose (fat) tissue. I do not see any evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this field of view. There are no atypical glands, nests of malignant cells, or large pleomorphic epithelial cells. The appearance is consistent with a reactive lymph node, which is negative for metastasis in this specific area. I would continue to scan the rest of this lymph node and all other nodes on the slide to confirm this finding.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image reveals the architecture of the lymph node in detail. I can see multiple well-defined lymphoid follicles, which are dense, round aggregates of lymphocytes. The cells within these follicles and in the surrounding paracortical areas are small, with dark, round nuclei and scant cytoplasm, consistent with benign lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical cells, glandular formations, necrosis, or other features suggestive of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows a benign, reactive lymph node with preserved architecture, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the normal lymph node architecture is completely replaced. There is a diffuse and dense infiltrate of malignant cells arranged in solid sheets and nests. The tumor cells are relatively monotonous, with round to slightly irregular, hyperchromatic (darkly stained) nuclei and scant to moderate amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm. Clear glandular structures are not readily apparent in this field, suggesting a poorly differentiated or solid pattern of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The pink, fibrillar material running through the tumor represents fibrovascular stroma. My impression is that this is a lymph node completely effaced by metastatic carcinoma, making it a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a section of a lymph node. The tissue is densely populated by a monotonous population of small, round lymphocytes with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. A large, dilated, empty space, likely a subcapsular or medullary sinus, is prominent. I do not see any definite clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or significant pleomorphism to suggest metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a portion of a lymph node. There is a dense, monotonous population of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are lymphocytes, characteristic of lymphoid parenchyma. At the top, there is the fibrous capsule of the lymph node and surrounding adipose tissue. There are some clear spaces within the lymphoid tissue, which could be dilated sinuses or artifact. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular formations, or nests of tumor cells. My impression of this specific area is that it represents a benign (reactive) lymph node, with no evidence of metastasis in this field of view.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see that the normal lymphoid architecture of the node is almost completely replaced by sheets of malignant cells. These cells are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma, likely from a colorectal primary. The most critical finding is at the periphery of the node (bottom and right side of the image), where clusters of tumor cells are clearly seen infiltrating through the lymph node capsule into the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. My impression is a positive lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma and definite extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see fragments of malignant glandular tissue. The glands are architecturally complex, crowded, and exhibit a cribriform (sieve-like) pattern. The cells lining these glands show significant nuclear atypia, with enlarged, hyperchromatic (darkly stained), and stratified nuclei. My impression is that this is a fragment of colorectal adenocarcinoma, representing a piece of the primary tumor. The features are consistent with a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Since the tissue is fragmented, it's not possible to assess the depth of invasion from this piece alone.
This is ROI 8. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals fragments of colonic mucosa with malignant features. I see irregularly shaped, crowded glands lined by atypical columnar epithelial cells. These cells show enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei with loss of polarity. These are the classic features of a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this fragment is from the primary tumor itself. The next step would be to carefully examine the interface of this tumor with any adjacent stroma, muscle, or adipose tissue to assess the depth of invasion (T stage) and to look for lymphovascular or perineural invasion.
This is ROI 9. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see multiple fragments of tissue composed of malignant glands. The glands are architecturally complex, with cribriform and back-to-back arrangements. The lining cells show significant atypia, including nuclear hyperchromasia, pleomorphism, and loss of polarity. This morphology is characteristic of an adenocarcinoma, consistent with a colorectal primary. There is no residual lymph node tissue or normal colonic wall structure visible in these specific fragments. My impression is that these are pieces of the primary adenocarcinoma, which might have been sampled separately or become fragmented during processing.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see the classic architecture of a lymph node. There is a dense population of small lymphocytes. Prominently, there are numerous well-formed, back-to-back lymphoid follicles, many with distinct germinal centers (the slightly paler, round areas) and surrounding mantle zones. This pattern is known as florid follicular hyperplasia. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or necrotic debris that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy. The changes seen are benign and likely a response to the nearby primary tumor.
This is ROI 11. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At high magnification, the dark, linear structure is clearly a non-biological foreign body. It has a fibrillar and folded appearance, which is characteristic of suture material. This suture is located directly adjacent to a fragment of lymphoid tissue, confirming it is within or next to a lymph node. The surrounding tissue includes adipose tissue and what appears to be the cortex of the lymph node. My impression is that this is a suture granuloma or simply an incidental suture within the dissected tissue block. The next step would be to carefully examine the adjacent lymphoid tissue for any signs of metastatic tumor cells.
This is ROI 12. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a section of a lymph node adjacent to mature adipose tissue. The lymph node architecture appears preserved, showing a dense population of lymphocytes. A well-defined germinal center is visible in the lower part of the node, indicating a reactive process. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or clusters of tumor cells that would suggest metastasis. The surrounding fat tissue is unremarkable. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 13 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms that this is a lymph node. The architecture is preserved with distinct lymphoid follicles. The cellular population consists predominantly of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. There are no identifiable clusters of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glandular structures, or extensive necrosis that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive or negative lymph node, free of metastatic tumor.
